definitions.definition: a common bird that lives on or near water and has short legs, webbed feet (= feet with thin pieces of skin between the toes) and a wide beak. There are many types of duck, some of which are kept for their meat or eggs.

examples.text: Every afternoon they went to the park to feed the ducks.
Ducks were quacking noisily on the lake.
A flock of ducks bobbed near the shore.
A rubber duck floated in the bath.
Some species of duck dive for food, while others dabble for plants and insects near the surface.
The ducks paddled furiously to grab the bread.
Slice the duck breast and serve.
In a large saucepan, melt the duck fat.

definitions.definition: a friendly way of speaking to somebody

examples.text: He was out for a duck.

definitions.definition: a plan, an event, etc. that has failed or is certain to fail and that is therefore not worth discussing
to have made all the preparations needed to do something; to be well organized

examples.text: The company has its ducks in a row for a move into the Asian market.
Get your ducks in a row before you retire.

definitions.definition: (to become used to something) very easily, without any problems or fears

examples.text: She has taken to teaching like a duck to water.

definitions.definition: used to say that something, especially criticism, has no effect on somebody/something

examples.text: I can't tell my son what to do; it's water off a duck's back with him.

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 3 Old English duce, from the Germanic base of duck in the verb sense (expressing the notion of ‘diving bird’). noun sense 5 mid 19th cent.: short for duck's egg, used for the figure 0 because of its similar outline. noun sense 4 late 16th cent.: from duck, the bird.
